passages.text: Price Objective Change

We revise our earnings estimates for Rengo, given containerboard- related price hikes at 1Q results trailing expectations, and revision of our assumption for the amount of impact from containerboard and corrugated packaging price hikes announced in July. Our price objective (PO) is based on P/E of 7.5x (was 6.5x) our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We factor in prospects for margin improvement from price hikes. We revise our operating profit (OP) estimate for FY3/26 from ¥45.3bn to ¥40.2bn (consensus ¥41.5bn), FY3/27 from ¥49.0bn to ¥49.6bn (¥48.7bn), and FY3/28 from ¥51.8bn to ¥51.0bn (¥51.7bn). We still expect corrugated packaging price hikes to drive margin improvement, and reiterate our Buy rating.

We trim our earnings estimates, given a decline in pulp prices, as well as smaller price hikes and sharper cost growth than we anticipated. Our PO is based on P/E of 10.0x (was 8.5x) our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We lower our OP estimate for FY3/26 from ¥73.1bn to ¥68.0bn (consensus ¥70.2bn), FY3/27 from ¥87.3bn to ¥86.0bn (¥86.9bn), and FY3/28 from ¥92.1bn to ¥91.4bn (¥94.9bn). We expect FY3/26 results to trail guidance, but reiterate our Neutral rating with a view to a rise in pulp prices and price hikes for domestic products.

We trim our earnings estimates, given our research since 1Q results. Our PO is based on P/E of 6.5x (was 6.0x) our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We take into account a rise in overall industry valuations. We lower our OP estimate for FY3/26 from ¥36.6bn to ¥35.3bn (consensus ¥37.8bn), FY3/27 from ¥41.1bn to ¥40.6bn (¥43.5bn), and FY3/28 from ¥42.3bn to ¥41.2bn (¥45.5bn). Although catalysts to increase growth potential are still not apparent, we reiterate our Neutral rating as we expect overall earnings improvement from progress in restructuring overseas business and price hikes in Japan.

Since June, sector companies starting with Oji HD have announced price hikes for containerboard and corrugated packaging. After that, Rengo's shares factored in the effects of the price hikes, and outperformed Oji and Rengo. We are somewhat cautious about price hikes gaining traction, but believe upside remains to Rengo's share price as it still looks undervalued.

Containerboard-related companies announced price hikes from JuneOji HD announced on 20 June containerboard and corrugated packaging price hikes, after which peers followed suit. While price hike amounts differ slightly, containerboard prices are to be raised by \(\yen 10 / kg\) from 1 October, with individual negotiations for corrugated packaging. Higher prices for raw materials, fuel, gas, labor, and logistics were cited as reasons for the price increases.

Oji HD and Rengo are integrated manufacturers, from containerboard to corrugated sheet, and corrugated boxes. Containerboard specialists would include Nippon Paper and Tokushu Tokai Paper. Among corrugated sheet and box makers are Tomoku, Dynapac and Nippon Tokan Package

As described above, sector companies have announced price hikes mainly because of higher costs. However, we think it will be challenging for companies to obtain the entire amount of the price hikes they seek, and expect delays in price hikes from October. This is because (1) prices have peaked out for containerboard (key raw material) and energy, (2) containerboard inventories are ample, and (3) contracts with major customers appear to be renewed in January. Also given that there has been a lag in price pass- through to products with price revisions in the past, we suspect raising prices as planned will be challenging this time too.

Given the above obstacles, we expect prices to increase for containerboard by \(\yen 5\) /kg from January 2026, and for corrugated packaging by \(\yen 3\) /m2 from April 2026. In that case, we envision limited impact on Rengo in FY3/26, but estimate a roughly \(\yen 7 - 8.5\) bn boost to its profit in FY3/27.

Given this boost to profit, we estimate Rengo's FY3/26 OP at \(\yen 40.2\) bn (consensus \(\yen 41.5\) bn) and FY3/27 OP at \(\yen 49.6\) bn ( \(\yen 48.7\) bn) (details for each segment discussed later). Our PO is based on a P/E of 7.5x our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We apply a multiple above Rengo's five- year average P/E of 6.5x, given prospects for margin improvement from price hikes. If Rengo makes upbeat comments about price hikes at its 2Q results briefing, further upside to valuations could emerge. In that case, we think a multiple of 8x, the upper end of Rengo's P/E range over the past five years, would be appropriate.

Our price objective (PO) is \(\yen 820\) . It is based on our FY3/27 EPS estimate and a P/E of 10x, a roughly \(20\%\) premium to Oji Holdings' five- year P/E average. We take into account improved shareholder returns in the new medium- term plan, and a reversal in pulp prices.

Upside risks to our PO are (1) a steep rise in pulp prices, (2) a sharp drop in prices for raw materials such as coal, (3) advancement of domestic market realignment, (4) rapid yen depreciation, and (5) improved shareholder returns. Downside risks are (1) a sharp drop in pulp prices, (2) a steep rise in raw material prices, (3) a sharper- than- expected decline in domestic market demand, (4) rapid yen appreciation, and (5) weaker shareholder returns.

Our price objective (PO) is \(\yen 1,280\) . It is based on our FY3/27 EPS estimate and a P/E of 6.5x, which applies a roughly \(30\%\) discount to Nippon Paper's five- year P/E average to reflect poor overseas business prospects.

Upside risks to our PO are (1) a sharp rise in paperboard prices in Southeast Asia, (2) a steep decline in prices for raw materials such as coal, (3) rapid yen appreciation, and (4) improved shareholder returns. Downside risks are (1) a sharp drop in paperboard prices in Southeast Asia, (2) a steep rise in prices for raw materials such as coal, (3) rapid yen depreciation, and (4) weaker shareholder returns.

Our price objective (PO) is \(\yen 1,050\) . It is based on our FY3/27 EPS estimate and a P/E of 7.5x, which applies a roughly \(15\%\) premium to Rengo's five- year P/E average to reflect prospect for margin improvement from price hikes.

Upside risks to our PO are (1) additional price hikes materializing, (2) a decline in recovered paper prices, (3) a sharp drop in raw material and fuel prices, (4) improved shareholder returns, and (5) rapid yen appreciation. Downside risks are (1) corrugated packaging price hikes failing, (2) sharp growth in recovered paper prices, (3) a steel price in raw material and fuel prices, (4) weaker shareholder returns, and (5) excessive yen depreciation.
